BE11:09am

In 2017 Tesla won the PR war, even if Chinese OEMs took the electric sales crown. But we expect EU premium carmakers to fight back in 2018/9. And it's not so much about headline-grabbing products (although the Porsche Mission E, Audi E-tron and Jag I-PACE are snapping at the heels of Tesla on range and performance), but about the more mundane war of production efficiency. Despite his vision for full factory automation, Elon Musk is sleeping on the factory floor again during his current Model 3 “production hell” woes and tweeting about his underuse of human workforce. We think German OEMs are about to launch an onslaught of attractive AND profitable electric products; we expect them to hit targets. The German (and Japanese) model of a harmonious blend of robot and human, perfected over 100 years of 'kaizen', together with the benefit of Industrie 4.0 will ensure a speedy and efficient production ramp.

If a hike does come, it could go against a global and European dovish tide. Sterling’s exchange rate might rise and greatly amplify the tightening effect of the rate hike.

BE11:33am

Back in February, when the Bank of England published its Inflation Report, it was expecting CPI
inflation of 3.0% y-o-y in January, which was right, but 2.9% in February (actual: 2.7%) and 2.8% in
March (actual: 2.5%). So, inflation has not just surprised the market to the downside, it has surprised the Bank too. Even with those forecasts, the Bank only expected CPI inflation to be marginally above target (at 2.11%) by the end of its forecast period (or 2.44% without rate rises). So it will be interesting to see what it does with those forecasts in May. As well as the downside surprises in outturns, sterling has also risen 2% since that February Inflation Report (though this will be offset a little by higher oil prices).
We still think the Bank is likely to raise interest rates in May. We have seen some downside surprises on growth and inflation in Q1 2018, but we think the MPC will focus on yesterday's labour market data: the unemployment rate dropped unexpectedly to 4.2% and regular pay growth picked up to 2.8% 3m/yr. However, unless the Bank raises its growth forecasts, then it will probably have to reduce its inflation forecasts. And if these come down much further, it will be projecting inflation at or even below target, reducing the urgency, we would have thought, for a sustained tightening cycle. This is in line with our view that there will be no further rate hikes after May (at least in our two year forecast period). We remain unpersuaded that domestically generated inflation is about to pick up, and today's inflation release only adds to our scepticism.

BE11:38am

BE11:39am

For Q118, Conti sees Rubber EBIT down €100m yoy, vs our estimate for flat. €150m is around 3% of group EBIT for FY18, so we expect a similar cut to consensus. This is clearly disappointing – in addition to the negative for FY18 numbers, we typically expect Conti to guide conservatively on the Rubber business and then progressively beat this through the year. From the 2016 profit warning on legacy warranty issues, we think Conti had rebuilt its reputation in the market for strong communication, which may come back into question. The issues seem to be around FX and inventory valuation, rather than volumes or pricing, and we haven't picked up anything of particular concern from market volume data or pricing commentary. We remain positive on tires earnings in general vs the rest of auto, but until Q1 numbers for volumes and price/mix are published, volume/pricing concerns may be the short-term discussion here.

BE11:39am

Barclays:

BE11:40am

We were already cautioning of softer margins in Rubber as a result of downward pressure on prices as raw materials have fallen and our Group forecasts for 2018 are also in line with the revised down company guidance at 10.4%. Our caution on Conti in recent months has focused more on the Automotive division that has suffered slower growth and which we worry has been at risk of over-investing and technology obsolescence. However, we have felt that Conti management has been addressing these issues much more confidently since the capital markets day in Vegas in January. The stock has underperformed the sector 5ppts YTD but from recent discussions with investors it seemed to us that longer-term money was now more willing to focus on opportunities for growth from 48V, future opportunities in connectivity and move away from the historical issues at Powertrain. Therefore a profit warning so early in the year, even if relatively small in size and related to factors outside of the company’s control, might keep some of these investors away. We reiterate our EW rating.

11:52 am

Canaccord:

BE11:53am

MONY had disappointed investors in February with the announcement of subdued growth (running at around half the rate of the broader price comparison market) and a further £5m investment in improving site optimisation (although continued weak performance in Money does support the argument for further investment in the site).

We see the Q1 update as reassuring, but there is little reason to change underlying forecasts at this stage. However, we are adjusting our assumptions to factor in the £40m Decision Tech acquisition (a mobile phone price comparison business, with both a B2B and B2C offering), which was announced on March 29th, but should complete in June. Decision Tech generated £3.6m of Ebitda in the year to March 2018, and we see that rising to £4.8m by FY19 (the first full year), given strong underlying revenue growth. We nudge up our FY18 PBT (norm) from £113.6m/16.9p to £114.1m/17.0p, but FY19 rises from £121.9m/18.2p to £124.7m/18.6p, a 2% upgrade. We still see year end net cash of £32m, and see scope for a resumption of share buy-backs at the time of its interims in August.

BE11:53am

MONY has bounced back from its post-downgrade lows, but still trades on a 15.3x 2019 PER, 10.5x EV/Ebitda.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

This looks inexpensive for an internet Media business, albeit one with limited short-term growth prospects. We would see potential cash returns with the interim results in August as a possible positive catalyst for the shares, but see limited upside in the short-term. Our 300p TP (unchanged) would represent an 11.0x 2019 EV/Ebitda. Hold.

On 1 March 2018, the Company announced:

- the Board had determined that a total of up to £50m of further investment would be required to fund the Company's acceleration plan;

- in the immediate term the Board would continue to focus on cash preservation; and

- as at 1st March 2018 the Company had cash balances of £3.5m, with future monthly outgoings forecast to be £0.75m per month.

The Company expects shortly to announce that it has secured interim funding via a loan of £1.5m from Lord Waheed Alli, a director of the Company. This interim funding will provide the Company with cash resources until the end of August 2018. On the basis this loan is entered into, it is expected to be classified as a related party transaction.

The Board actively continues the previously announced dialogue with potential new investors in respect of the £50m funding requirement and will update the market in due course.
